thread.title: Boys soccer: Clifton High School heads to county semifinals
thread.title_full: Boys soccer: Clifton High School heads to county semifinals

title: Boys soccer: Clifton High School heads to county semifinals
text:
Buy this photo Staff photo/Marko Georgiev Clifton's Facundo Frascolla and Passaic County Tech's Felix Benitez go up for the ball in their county matchup last weekend. 
Bruno Frascolla and Clifton authored a fairytale ending on Tuesday night. 
"I'd say it was more like redemption," Frascolla said. 
Indeed it was salvation on a cool evening at Clifton School Stadium when the Mustangs picked off previously undefeated Bergen Tech, 1-0, in a pulsating Big North Conference Liberty Division boys' soccer contest. 
Frascolla buried a penalty kick after only 38 seconds of the first overtime and, poof, Clifton moved to within a game of the Liberty leaders, improving to 9-3 overall and 4-2 in the league. Bergen Tech slumped to 9-1 and 5-1. 
What made Frascolla's golden goal, well, golden, was erasing a bit of painful history. Rewind back to Sept. 10 when the Mustangs trailed by a goal late at the Techsters. Frascolla smashed a penalty kick which goalkeeper Brandon Duffy blocked. Tech eventually won, 3-2. 
"He made a great save that day," said the tall Uruguayan defender and primary penalty kick specialist. 
That wasn't the case on Tuesday. 
Following a goalless 80 minutes, Clifton gained possession in the midfield with Facundo Frascolla—yes Bruno's freshman brother—hitting speedy sophomore Michael Algieri on the left wing. Algieri's cross clipped the arm of a Bergen Tech defender in the penalty area, allowing Bruno Frascolla to add a footnote to the his brilliant prep career. 
Duffy had no chance this time as Frascolla slammed a right-footed shot from the shot into the upper-left corner. 
Redemption for Frascolla but more importantly a sixth-consecutive win for the Mustangs. 
"We're only one game back in the Liberty but I told the team that we can only take care of our games and will need some help from the rest of the league," said Clifton second-year boss Stan Lembryk, whose side played at rival Passaic on Thursday. 
Clifton had the better of the run of play in the opening stanza. 
After a few tactical adjustments at the break, the Mustangs pushed for a breakthrough moment and nearly had it when Algieri slipped a pass in the area to Facundo Frascolla, who crushed a right-footed drive at Duffy (five saves). 
Clifton's compact defending excelled, with right back Alex Guzman and Bruno Frascolla keeping things tidy. 
"We played tight and didn't let them go through," Guzman said. "We pressured them [Bergen Tech] all over the field and made sure their top goal scorers wouldn't get good looks. Most importantly we got the clean sheet." 
Tech's Alex Whang delivered a hard shot from 30 yards that sophomore 'keeper Jake Padula handled easily midway through the second stanza, but that was it for the Knights. 
The focus shifts back to a knockout match this weekend. 
The Mustangs have the benefit of playing the Passaic County Coaches' Association Tournament at home in this Saturday's semifinal match with ninth-seeded Wayne Valley at 4 p.m. The opening match is Hawthorne Christian Academy and Wayne Hills at 2. 
The regular season continues with El Clasico II on Tuesday when Passaic County Tech invades the Stadium at 5 o'clock. Then the Mustangs travel to Paterson for a league match with Kennedy at 4 in Paterson. 
Last Saturday, the Mustangs pushed through to the Passaic County Tournament semifinals, eliminating fourth-seeded Passaic County Tech, 2-1, in Wayne. The Bulldogs conceded both goals in the first half. 
Senior Frankie Salensky and Algieri staked the Mustangs to the insurmountable lead. © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
